To start from the beginning, I don’t think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for the war before invading Iraq. I think there was an attempt to link the invasion of Iraq to the terrorist attacks of September 11th when in reality, one didn’t have that much to do with the other. The government made it seem that way to play on the emotions of the American people in their outrage against the terrorist attacks of September 11th 2001 and the invasion of Iraq started in 2003.
I myself am pretty much against war, especially to make a preemptive strike. I was against that. The war in Iraq is kind of a repeat in many ways of the Vietnam War. The government should have learned from past mistakes that they have made.
A tremendous amount of American soldiers have died, and that’s horrible. What they were doing was removing the country’s government and I really don’t think the government was prepared for the aftermath and the void of power and the chaos that was going to occur.
The United States is removing the Iraqi government and they are trying to implant a democratic government. It’s kind of a similar thing they were trying to do in Vietnam, pushing out Communists and upholding or implementing democracy.
And it’s going to be a long and hard ordeal that probably wasn’t going to be a clear clear victory like it wasn’t a clear victory in Vietnam because there are insurgents and it’s hard to put them down when you’re not fighting an actual army, you’re fighting the citizens in the country.
So first of all, I think we shouldn’t have gotten into war cause I’m against it in pretty much all cases. But if you are going to go to war, you need to be prepared for all possible outcomes. I think the government was not as prepared as it should have been. They weren’t planning for what would happen once they removed the Iraqi government. We’re still there today and many American troops are still dying.
Many Iraqis wanted the US to come in. We’re the ones who took away their government and their way of life. How can we abandon them now? It’s probably something we should try to see to its finish, but there’s also the consideration of the astronomical amount of American casualties and how much is too much to keep risking for a free democratic Iraq? Going back to the whole reason for invading Iraq, why is it just Iraq? Why aren’t we doing this to all these other countries? I think it’s because of the oil issue. It’s usually all about money and controlling resources.
In the election of 2004, one of my reasons for voting for George Bush was to let him finish what he started. Once you go in there, how can we abandon these people? We’re the ones who took away their government and their way of life. So it’s probably something we should try to see to its finish, but there’s also the consideration of the astronomical amount of American casualties and how much is too much to keep risking for a free democratic Iraq.
I hope it ends soon and there will be peace there soon, but probably not.

I strongly support gay marriage. I've always believed it's a personal preference and more of a biological trait than something chosen. It's not fair to deny people rights based on something they can't control. It's inhumane. I've been an advocate for it for a long time. I don't think politics or government should interfere at this level. It's a personal and household issue. In my neighborhood, there are openly gay couples who function just like any other family. They walk their dogs, just like anyone else. I find it ridiculous that politicians like Bush claim to interpret the meaning of marriage, especially when two people can marry secretly without anyone knowing, but if two gay people want to marry, it becomes a national issue. I believe it should be a private, personal matter, not a public one. I don't think it's fair to make it such a big deal.

When you post something online, it's public knowledge. As an R.A., I've encountered this firsthand. Whatever you put out there is going to influence people's opinions of you, especially if it's about sensitive topics like shootings or bomb threats. The internet is visible to everyone, and if you're friends with someone on Myspace, you'll see their bulletin. If something serious is said, the school has to act on it, even if it seems like a joke. There's no invasion of privacy when it's brought to their attention, but if you don't want something out there, you shouldn't post it. You can't control what people think or how seriously they take your posts. Personally, I think school officials shouldn't be friends with students online or snooping through their profiles, but if a concern is raised, they have to take it seriously. I wouldn't friend my residents because I don't want to see their personal activities, and it's not my place to police their actions online.

I feel that the war has dragged on far too long. Initially, the purpose seemed noble: to restore democracy in a country lacking a fair political system. However, I believe we've lost sight of that goal and are now at war merely to assert our status as a superpower. The original motivations may have been tainted by personal interests, notably George Bush's father's past conflicts with Saddam Hussein. If the true purpose was to bring democracy, it was a just cause, but the war has become a protracted affair, with the initial goals diluted. The war has dragged on for years, and I believe it's time to end it. The country's officials should now take the lead. We've been draining our own resources, spending billions on a war that no longer aligns with our original purpose. There are pressing issues at home that need our attention, such as poverty and infrastructure improvement. The money being spent on this war could be much better allocated to domestic issues.

Can I ask a question to clarify something?

Well, I'm not sure if this happened because someone went online and found something, but okay, let me ask you.

Um, no, I don't think that's an invasion of privacy.

On sites like Myspace, if you post personal information, it's generally available for anyone to see. I mean, you have to accept that when you're sharing something online.

I understand that you might need to be friends with someone to view their profile, but if that's the case, you've already given them permission to see it.

So, whenever you put something on the internet, you should know that many people are going to see it. If someone saw something online that helped prevent a life being lost, that's tough because it's not like you can't have one person sitting around looking at everyone's profiles all day.

It becomes a form of discrimination if you think, "Let's check the bad kids to make sure they're not up to anything." However, it all depends on the situation they stumbled upon the profile in. Maybe they were just casually browsing or looking for evidence that a student was planning something.

I don't have a Myspace myself, but I do use Facebook. It bothers me knowing that there are creepy people out there who can see things about me. I've seen a TV show where a man proved how easily he could get information from a girl's profile and even convinced her to meet him in less than a minute. I would never do that, but I know people in my class who I don't recognize but know my screen name. It's hard because they might know my interests, what I look like, and even my daily schedule.

I try to limit what I share, but I also want to communicate with my friends. It's a tricky issue because I only accept friend requests from people I know. You never know who can see what.

One of my roommates told me that in high school, students were banned from using Myspace by the school. I thought that was a bit strange. I'm not sure how high school officials had the right to tell their students they couldn't have a Myspace.

It just feels like an invasion of privacy, and I'm not sure if they have that authority. That's the only other thought I can think of.

Yes.

Well, I guess I only have two things to talk about concerning the Iraq War. I mean, it's not easy to discuss because I feel like a hypocrite joining in on the "I was against it from the start" crowd. But, let's face it, it's just not that significant anymore, right?

I mean, almost everyone agrees that it was a bad idea. Look at the polls – 75 to 80% of the world thinks it was a mistake, including 80% of Iraqis and 70% of the troops over there. It's been a complete mess since the beginning, and pulling out will also be a disaster. The Middle East is just too complicated. The culture clash is huge, and previous administrations didn't seem to get that. It's like they thought they could just march in and impose democracy, but it's not that simple.

I'm not saying Saddam wasn't a bad guy, but you have to weigh the pros and cons before invading a country. We got stuck in quicksand over there. I don't know what to say about it anymore. I don't see a reason to stay. The administration might have some ideas on why we should stay, but so far I haven't heard a good one.

I read that 80% of Iraqis want us to leave within the year, and at least a quarter want us to go now. These are the people we're trying to help, and they're telling us to leave. Shouldn't we at least listen to them? And if we do leave, we'll be the good guys, you know, if something goes wrong, we can say we were going to stay but they wanted us to leave.

But, you know, we'll probably never be seen as the good guys in the Middle East, no matter what we do. But it's better than where we are now.

I do indeed believe that gender discrimination is still a significant issue in the United States. It's not limited to women; I think it also affects individuals in specific fields and regions. For instance, many women struggle with the "glass ceiling" in professional environments, where even qualified candidates are passed over for promotions due to societal expectations. Similarly, men in certain industries, such as fashion, often face skepticism and lower expectations because of traditional gender roles. I believe that change is gradual, but it is happening. Women are increasingly taking on higher positions and being more accepted in the business world, as are men who choose to stay at home to care for their children. However, promoting these changes takes time and must be done subtly, without forcing the issue. Discrimination also exists based on socioeconomic background and education, with those from lower socioeconomic backgrounds facing additional challenges. Despite these obstacles, progress is being made, and society is slowly adopting more inclusive attitudes.

It seems to me that they haven’t made it legal, but they've decriminalized it, which means that having marijuana has been downgraded from a criminal offense to something more like a traffic ticket. Basically, if you get caught, you'll be cited rather than arrested and brought in for booking. This change in classification can have significant implications, especially with job interviews and other situations where a drug charge could be a major negative. While decriminalization doesn't eliminate these legal concerns, it does reduce the severity of them. On the other hand, there's an argument that it's a cost-effective change for municipalities, given that arresting, booking, and prosecuting individuals for marijuana possession is expensive. This financial aspect can be particularly appealing for communities that are under financial strain. For instance, in a place like Denver, where people tend to be more liberal, decriminalizing marijuana can lead to greater financial resources for public education, social programs, and assistance for the elderly and homeless. While I understand that marijuana shouldn't be openly sold and smoked on the streets due to its taboo nature in many places, I think the financial benefits are worth considering. However, it's important to note that both alcohol and marijuana have their own adverse effects on individuals, and it's difficult to generalize about how people react to substances. Unlike alcohol, marijuana might have a more significant impact on lifestyle than just motor skills.

I'd agree that yes, a lot of the things the Catholic Church does are deeply rooted in tradition, which can be a positive aspect. By maintaining these traditions, they stay connected to their history and values. However, it's also crucial to be adaptable and open to change. A significant portion of Catholics believe that attending Church every week is mandatory, and they adhere strictly to the rules and practices. Unfortunately, this can sometimes lead to a lack of acceptance towards those who don't follow the doctrine perfectly or belong to other religions. For instance, my parents' interfaith marriage couldn't be blessed in the Catholic Church due to my dad's Episcopalian background. While the Church teaches to love others, their actions often contradict this by not accepting those who are not "perfect" Catholics or belong to other religions. This paradoxical approach can make it feel outdated and hypocritical. I believe that, at least in theory, allowing priests to marry might be a good idea. However, I'm not convinced that it would solve the issue of pedophilic behavior among priests. Child molestation is a separate issue from marital status. Allowing priests to marry might not necessarily deter such behavior, as it's more about the individual's personal inclinations than their marital status. I don't think priests would suddenly stop molesting children just because they're married.

Oh, I'm still undecided on this issue, to be honest. It's such a divisive topic, straddling the delicate line between church and state, and how we define marriage. I mean, it's tricky to talk about without stepping on someone's toes. I don't know, I think civil unions should just be recognized as they are, without any government interference. I mean, if two people are united, it shouldn't matter what kind of union it is, right? And if all states can agree on a solution, then they should push for a federal law. But amending the constitution just to ban gay marriage? That's just absurd! The constitution shouldn't be amended for something that's not a broad enough cause to warrant it. It's just not important enough to change the constitution over. Simply put, no.

I grew up in a Christian household, so like many others, the topic of homosexuality is somewhat of a grey area for me. While I have several gay friends, I personally don't align with that lifestyle, but I do believe that it should be legalized. I don't think it should be an issue at the national level; rather, it should be left up to each state to decide. States are diverse in their political leanings, with many being democratic or republican. Democratic states are likely to favor gay marriage, while republican states might not. Living in a state, you should respect its stance on the matter since you've chosen to reside there. I believe homosexuals should have equal opportunities as heterosexuals, and based on that, I think each state should make the decision to legalize it. I don't agree with President Bush imposing his views on the entire country on this matter. He shouldn't be able to dictate how each state should run itself, as he won't be around forever. If a Democratic president reverses the ban on gay marriage, it would just be a game of political ping-pong. It's best to leave it up to each state to decide, as they'll be the ones to live with the consequences, not the president.

Let me put it this way, there's no doubt that Myspace is a public forum. If you look up the definition, you'll see that it's designed for public viewing. So, when you post something on the internet, you should be aware that it can be seen by anyone, including school officials. And if they're doing it to keep students safe, I see no problem with that. After all, isn't the safety of students a responsibility of the school system? But, if they're just going on the internet to catch students in trouble, I'd say that's an invasion of privacy. However, if they're using it to make the school safer, like preventing a school shooting, I think it's perfectly fine. I mean, if it saves lives, isn't that what's important? But, if they're using it just to catch students, that's a step too far. It's like when you're in college, you're already worried about what you say in emails. You don't want anything coming back to haunt you later. And once it's on the internet, it's there forever. You can't take it back. So, if they're using it to make the school safer, that's one thing. But if they're just using it to catch students, that's a different story. That's not an invasion of privacy if it's to keep the students safe.

Ok
Um
The war
Um
At first, I was quite supportive of the war because I was personally affected by 9/11. I was all for going over there and causing as much chaos as they did here. However, as time passed, I realized that we may have overlooked a lot of key factors and didn't thoughtfully consider the long-term implications. We seemed to have rushed into it without a proper plan, and I believe it ultimately backfired. I don't know if I'm being fair, but I was all for it initially. Now, I'm very much against it, as I feel it hasn't achieved anything significant. I think the people over there are more focused on fighting each other than us. They can't even manage their own lives, so I don't see how we can impose our will on them. I almost don't care about what happens over there now. It's like, they fight among themselves, and that's that. We definitely went over there unprepared, not knowing what to expect. War is different for them; they're more brutal, and I don't think they're looking to improve their country. They just want us out. I think it would be best for us to leave and let them handle their own affairs. We were more driven by emotion and anger than rational thought. I think President Bush declared war on Iraq because the people demanded it, and he felt he had to act. At the time, I understood where he was coming from; they can't just do something like that and expect us to just let it slide. We had to respond, but I believe we could have handled it more strategically. We didn't have a clear plan for what to do once we got there. I don't think we really united behind a common goal, and that might have helped us more. Honestly, I don't think we're the right ones to change them. They'll always be the same. I don't think we're making enough progress. We've made some, but not enough to justify staying there. No matter how long we stay, it's just going to collapse once we leave. And we can't stay there forever. I think we're hurting ourselves by staying there. No, let's just leave.

transformed_texts: I believe that in several ways, the Catholic Church could benefit from some changes. They have been discussing how their following is declining, and I believe it's because they are often quite rigid in their views on various topics. For instance, they're strongly opposed to gay marriage, abortion, and birth control, which can make it difficult for those with differing opinions to feel welcomed. If the Church were to adopt a more contemporary mindset, I think they could maintain a strong base of followers. I've also heard that more people are turning against the Church due to their stance on these issues, and it's causing a bit of a division. While the Church is against abortion, if someone is for it, they might not want to be part of a community that sees it as completely wrong. Similarly, if someone supports gay marriage, they might not want to follow a Church that doesn't agree with that. I don't see a reason why priests couldn't be married or why women couldn't be priests. However, I'm not sure if these changes would have prevented the declining following. After all, the Church did something that might not have been affected by these changes. If priests were allowed to marry, would they have done things differently? It's hard to say. However, I don't see why priests can't have both their religious devotion and their family life, just like everyone else.

I'm not opposed to gay marriage. I believe that whether someone is gay or not is not a conscious choice they make. So I don't think gay people should be held responsible for their sexual orientation. It's not right to say that a man and a woman can get married but two people of the same sex can't. It's not a choice like they don't have a say in how they are born. I mean, I was born straight, and I didn't choose that either. It doesn't seem like they can be held accountable for something they can't change. I don't think the federal government should be involved because it's not a legal or moral issue. It's not about national security or anything like that. They shouldn't interfere in people's lives because being gay is just how they were born. They shouldn't be punished for that. That's it.

I believe that gay marriage should be legalized. Here are some reasons why:

Many people argue that allowing same-sex couples to marry would pose a threat to traditional families, but I think it’s a misconception. The dynamics of a relationship are so varied and complex that comparing it to something as simple as a coin isn’t quite accurate. Heterosexual and homosexual couples have the same basic elements that contribute to a successful and satisfying relationship, like love, commitment, and shared values.

Moreover, many civil rights protections are tied to marriage, such as property rights and healthcare benefits. For instance, a partner in a same-sex relationship might not be allowed to visit their spouse in the hospital, and they might not be able to make medical decisions on behalf of their partner. This can be unfair if you’re spending the rest of your life with someone.

Scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples are just as successful as heterosexual couples, with similar factors contributing to relationship satisfaction. It’s a relationship, plain and simple. Many people seem to get hung up on the idea that homosexuals are asking for the right to get married in a church, but what they’re really asking for is a legal document provided by the government. If there’s no involvement from the church, I don’t see why there should be an issue.

Legalizing gay marriage is similar to the segregation but separate issue. It’s unfair and unequal. Just like heterosexual couples, homosexual couples can take on different roles in the relationship, and they have the same potential for community involvement. The concern about children of gay couples is a valid one, but it’s too early to say how they’ll be affected. The main concern is how children get treated by their peers and by society, which is often a reflection of societal attitudes.

The federal government should be actively involved in making gay marriage legal in every state. I think an amendment should be crafted that supports, rather than opposes, this right. However, I’m not sure about the political aspects, as I don’t follow politics closely. Most of the reasons I’ve heard, including from President Bush, are based on moral grounds. Morality is highly subjective and varies from person to person, so it’s unethical to create laws that enforce one group’s morality on the entire country.

It’s also important to note that many people are against gay marriage because they believe that gay people are somehow psychologically damaged and that their sexual orientation is a result of trauma or a personality defect. This is not backed by psychological research. Institutions that have studied these issues, like the American Psychological Association, have shown that this misconception is false. If more people listened to these institutions and less to popular opinion, societal attitudes might change.

In conclusion, I believe that legalizing gay marriage is the right thing to do. It’s about love and commitment, and it should be treated with the same respect and dignity as any other relationship.

Well first off, I work in a hospital pharmacy this summer and let me tell you, just because a drug is outlawed doesn't mean it lacks beneficial properties. Take oxycodone, for instance—it's a controlled substance, but we use it all the time because it's beneficial. Similarly, I'm not saying I'd put marijuana out there for the public to use freely, but I think it can have medicinal benefits when used responsibly.

You know, there are so many illegal drugs that pharmacies use every day. Vicodin, Percocet—those are known to be addictive, but they're used because they're beneficial. Denying that doesn't make sense to me. I think we should embrace the beneficial properties of marijuana, but it's got to be done responsibly.

I don't think marijuana is as bad as the taboo around it suggests. It's not like heroin or cocaine. I'd say we should gradually integrate it into society, removing the stigma first. Then, perhaps people could use it responsibly. It's a tough call, but I think it's worth considering.

I believe the church has evolved to adapt to the 21st century. It's no longer as rigid as it once was. As a child, I would attend church every Sunday, dressed in matching outfits with my friends from our private school. Nowadays, the church has introduced youth services, which are much shorter, and people are more casual, even arriving in beachwear during the summer. The morning masses have also relaxed, with people wearing jeans and khakis. While I'm unsure of the church's political stance, this is the most significant change I've noticed. Regarding the accusations against Catholic priests and pedophilia, I think these issues could not have been prevented by changes like allowing female priests or married priests. Pedophilia is often linked to genetics, not just the environment. Even if priests were allowed to marry, their predispositions wouldn't change. If a man is genetically inclined to be a pedophile, he would likely still act on it, regardless of his marital status. I believe the church could have done more to address these issues if they were aware and covering them up, but I suspect not all cases were known.

(Laughs)
Initially, I was okay with the initial premise, but I think that everyone was still very much in shock from the September 11th attacks. And I believe that we invaded Iraq under a false pretext, that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction and was connected to the attacks. But all of this has since been proven false, and it really rubs me the wrong way. It just seems to me that the Bush administration openly lied to the American people and has yet to take responsibility for those lies.

Colin Powell, for instance, has said that he wasn't convinced by the evidence he presented at the UN. That's malfeasance in office, an impeachable offense. The Bush administration has shown a complete disregard for the Constitution, trying to marginalize it since September 11th. They came into office with a clear intention to go to war. Paul O’Neill, the Secretary of the Treasury who was seemingly forced out of his office, mentioned this in his book. It seems that the younger Bush had a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein, and he wanted to expand our energy supply in the long term.

I think the war has gone on long enough, but I'm not sure if pulling out now would be a good idea. The country could lapse into civil war and result in even more deaths. The alternative, a coalition of nations from surrounding areas like Syria and Saudi Arabia, doesn't seem ideal either, as it could lead to more problems with Iraq's sovereignty. The interim government seems to be dissolving, and the Parliament isn't very effective. The political process is also experiencing a lot of friction due to radical elements vying for control.

I can't articulate these thoughts in polite company.

But it's not a good enough reason to stay. If we leave, they'll be upset because we'll have messed everything up. They'll have to start over, and it'll take forever for them to build a democracy. I don't think it's right to legalize it, and I don't believe a state should even declare it legal. I feel this is really up to the churches, as the constitution states separation of church and state. It's explicitly clear, and I don't think trying to impose any power over it would be right, as it goes against what's already in the constitution. In my opinion, trying to enforce any kind of power over it would be in defiance of what has already been said and written in stone.

I think those who are trying to make it illegal are choosing one church's beliefs over another. Most Catholics and Christians are against it, and don't support it, except for in Boston and some areas like that. I don't think it's up to the government to decide what churches can and can't make illegal or legal. Separation of church and state has been a key aspect of the constitution, allowing for religious tolerance in the United States. I don't think making an amendment about it would be right or even contradictory to what's already been said and written. It would be one of the few amendments that would restrict the people rather than the government.

I don't believe the federal government, or any government, should be involved in this issue. The push for this amendment is likely driven by personal religious beliefs, as the person pushing it is a Catholic. Their push for the amendment is just showing a preference for their religion over others. I really feel it's up to the churches to decide this, not the president or any government official. There isn't any substantial reason backing it up, other than personal views. I don't see how it's going to impact the economy or society in any significant way, and in fact, it might have a positive impact on society.

The war in Iraq is a topic that has sparked much debate over the years. Let me start by saying I believe that the government was not fully truthful with the American people about the reasons for going to war. I think the invasion was seen as a way to connect Iraq to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, when in reality, the two events had little to do with each other. The government played on the emotions of the American people, who were outraged by the September 11th attacks, to gain support for the invasion, which began in 2003.

I personally am against war, especially preemptive strikes. I believe that the war in Iraq is, in many ways, a repeat of the Vietnam War. The government failed to learn from past mistakes and was not prepared for the aftermath of removing the Iraqi government and the chaos that would ensue. The United States was removing the Iraqi government and trying to implement a democratic government, similar to what was attempted in Vietnam. However, the government did not anticipate the insurgency that would arise, as fighting citizens rather than a well-defined army is much more challenging.

Firstly, I don't think we should have gotten into the war in the first place. But if we were to engage in war, we need to plan for all possible outcomes. I believe the government was not as prepared as it should have been. They did not anticipate the void of power and the chaos that would occur after removing the Iraqi government. Despite being there for several years, the United States is still trying to train Iraqi troops and police forces to police their own country. It's a long process, and I think the government made it seem like it would be a short, successful stay in Iraq.

The war in Iraq is a tough decision to make because we've been there for so long. Once we've committed to a war, it's hard to abandon the people we've removed the government from. We took away their way of life, so how can we abandon them? It's a difficult choice between trying to finish the job and considering the risk we're taking for a free democratic Iraq. The question of why Iraq was invaded while other countries with known weapons of mass destruction, like North Korea, were not, raises the issue of the oil industry. It's a complex issue with a lot of money and resource control at play.

I just hope that the war ends soon and that there will be peace in Iraq. But I'm not optimistic that this will happen anytime soon.

Let's see, I've always been in support of gay marriage. I believe it's a personal preference, and science has shown that it's often biological rather than sociological, making it unfair to deny rights based on something that's largely out of people's control. It's also cruel and inhumane. I've been an advocate for it for a long time. I don't think politics or the government should play a role, as it's a personal and household issue, not something to be decided at the state or national level. In my neighborhood, there are a couple of openly gay couples who function just like any other family. Bush's attempt to interpret marriage in his own way is ridiculous. Maybe it's because marriage is something two people can choose to do privately without much fuss, but if two gay people want to do it, it becomes a public spectacle. I think it should be a private, personal matter, not something the public or government gets involved in.

No, there's no turning back.

You know, when you share something online, it's basically a public forum. Everything you put out there is visible to everyone. It can shape people's opinions about you, especially if it's something serious, like talking about violence or harmful activities. The internet is a global platform, and if you're friends with someone on Myspace, their bulletins will show up on your page. Someone at school might see something concerning and report it, as they can't afford to ignore potential threats. However, some people might just be fooling around, making it hard to discern what's serious. In our school, someone overheard a concerning statement and reported it to the authorities. They found that the person had made some worrying posts on Facebook that could have been taken seriously. So, if you don't want something to be public, don't put it online. If you don't want people to find it or form certain opinions, you can't control that. If you're an R.A. and you're friends with your residents on social media, you might see posts that you don't want to see, like pictures of them drinking or engaging in other activities. While I don't think school officials should friend students, if something is brought to their attention, they have a responsibility to take it seriously. They shouldn't be monitoring phone conversations or texts, but if they receive a report about a potential threat, they have to act accordingly.

I feel like the war has been stretched out too long. Initially, the purpose was noble—to restore democracy in a country without a fair political system. But I believe we've lost sight of that aim and now we're just fighting to prove our global dominance. Perhaps there were even personal motivations tied to George Bush's father's previous conflicts with Saddam Hussein. If the original intention was to bring democracy to a tyrannical regime, that would be justifiable. However, I think our reasons have become muddled and our purpose has been lost over time, as we seem to be fighting for the sake of fighting. I believe it has dragged on long enough and should come to a conclusion soon. After all, there comes a point when the local government must take charge. We've been draining our own economy by spending billions on a foreign war while facing our own domestic issues like poverty and infrastructure. This money could be better spent on addressing our own pressing needs, such as healthcare and school improvements. War is not a long-term expense, and there are more pressing issues to address. The ongoing war is a drain on our resources that could be more effectively used to solve our own problems.

Can I ask a question to clarify something? Someone found that post online and took action to prevent it because of what they saw. I don't think it was an invasion of privacy at all. On sites like Myspace, if you post information publicly, it's fair game for anyone to see, as long as you're okay with it. Maybe the person who saw the post was doing their job, or maybe they were just curious. Either way, I'm glad they intervened and prevented a life from being lost.

It's a tough situation, though. You can't have one person monitoring everyone's profiles all day, but it's not fair to target only certain students. It all depends on the situation. I don't have a Myspace, but I do have a Facebook, and it bothers me knowing that strangers can see personal information about me. I've seen things on TV where people can find out so much about others just by looking at their profiles.

I've had people IM me and know who I am without me knowing their screen name. It's disconcerting to think that someone knows my interests, where I am during the day, and who my friends are. I try to limit what I post, but at the same time, I want to communicate with friends. It's a tricky situation, and I only accept people I know as friends.

My roommate's high school banned students from having Myspace, which I thought was strange. I'm not sure how they had the right to do that.

I must admit, I feel that gender discrimination is still a significant issue in the United States. It's not confined to women but affects various fields and roles, often based on societal expectations and stereotypes.

For instance, in the workplace, women continue to face challenges in breaking through the "glass ceiling." Even when they possess all the necessary qualifications, some boards may hesitate to promote them to top positions simply because historically women have not held such roles in the business world.

Moreover, men also experience discrimination, particularly in fields like fashion or when they choose to stay at home as primary caregivers. Society often expects men to be the sole breadwinners, leading to judgment and disapproval when they deviate from this norm.

In the fashion industry, men are sometimes not taken seriously due to their interest in a field traditionally dominated by women. This can lead to doubts about their understanding and experience with women's fashion.

Regardless of the field, I believe gender discrimination persists due to societal setbacks in mindset and acceptance. While significant progress has been made, societal changes take time. Women are increasingly moving into leadership roles, and men are becoming more accepted as primary caregivers, but these shifts are gradual.

To effect change, we need to promote the positive qualities of those stereotypically discriminated against, rather than being overly insistent. If we attempt to enforce change too quickly, people may resist. I believe we're already on the right path, with women rising to higher positions and men being more accepted in traditional female roles. However, we must continue to work at this pace to ensure sustained progress.

Furthermore, discrimination can also occur based on factors like socioeconomic background and grammar. For example, someone from a farm with excellent intelligence but poor grammar might face judgments from others, underscoring the multifaceted nature of discrimination.

In conclusion, while significant strides have been made, there's still much work to be done to achieve true equality across all areas of society.

In my opinion, decriminalization is the new approach to marijuana laws, which changes it from a criminal offense to more of a minor infraction, similar to a traffic ticket. This means that people caught with marijuana are cited rather than arrested. However, the long-term consequences of a marijuana charge, such as the stigma in job interviews and other areas of life, still exist.

There's an argument that decriminalization could save money for communities that are financially struggling. The costs of arrests, trials, and legal representation can be significant. In places like Denver, where people generally hold more open-minded views, decriminalization is well-received, freeing up money for public education, social programs, and other community needs.

While I understand the financial benefits, I also believe in being cautious about the public's perception of marijuana. Legalization could lead to it being sold and used openly, much like cigarettes, which could be awkward and problematic in many contexts. Additionally, the effects of marijuana can differ greatly from person to person, with some people being more adversely affected than others.

I don't have a strong opinion one way or the other, but I think it's important to consider all the factors involved.

I'd say yes, because
- A lot of what they do is quite traditional, like they've maintained certain practices for long periods of time.
- It's good to stay connected to tradition, but it's also important to be adaptable to change.
- Many Catholics feel obligated to attend Church every week and are quite strict about how things are done.
- Sometimes, I feel like the Catholic Church looks down on those who don't fully adhere to the doctrine.
- They also aren't very accepting of other religions, as seen in the case of my parents' interfaith marriage.
- My mom was an Episcopalian, and my dad was also Episcopalian. Despite their love for each other, they weren't married in the Catholic Church due to my dad's religious background.
- This isn't really a display of tolerance for other religions.
- We've been taught to love others, which is a Catholic principle, but it's hypocritical to say one thing and then not act on it.
- I feel that a lot of Catholic doctrine dictates specific actions, but the actual practice often goes against these teachings.
- I don't think allowing priests to marry would necessarily stop pedophilic behavior.
- Children are much more vulnerable than spouses, so I think child molestation would happen regardless of whether priests are married or not.
- Allowing priests to marry wouldn't solve the problem of pedophilic behavior.

I grew up in a Christian household, so my stance on homosexuality is a bit complicated. I have many gay friends, but I don’t necessarily agree with their lifestyle. However, I believe it should be legalized. I don’t think it should be a national issue, but rather something each state decides on its own. For instance, many states are Democratic, and they tend to push for gay marriage. If you live in a Democratic state, you should respect the state's decision on the matter. I think homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I feel it should be legalized based on the discretion of each state. I don't agree with President Bush's ban on gay marriage; he shouldn't be able to decide how every state runs itself. He won't be in office for much longer, and if a Democratic president decides to lift the ban, it would just be a back-and-forth battle. It should be left up to each individual state, as they are the ones who will have to live with the decision. I don't think it should be a matter for the presidency to decide.

No way, no I don't at all. Let me see, I think it's like this: Myspace is public, and a bulletin board is a place where you post things for others to see. If you put something on the internet, you should expect that people will see it, whether it's school officials or not. If they see something that could prevent a school shooting, they have every right to do so. It's all about keeping students safe. School officials should only use it to make the school safer, not just to catch students doing something wrong. It's okay if they do it to protect students, but they shouldn't just snoop around. It's a public space, and students should know that. They shouldn't post things they don't want others to see. If they do, they should expect consequences. Once it's on the internet, it's there forever. It's just like not wanting to say something bad about someone in an email because it could come back to haunt you. Same with posting on Myspace. If you do something in college, it could come back when you're older. It's all about being careful with what you post. If something could make the school safer, school officials should use it. They're just doing their job to keep students safe. It's like how we practiced lock downs in school in response to terrorist attacks. They're just ensuring the school is a safe space for students.

transformed_texts: I believe that in several ways, the Catholic Church could benefit from some changes. They have been discussing how their following is declining, and I believe it's because they are often quite rigid in their views on various topics. For instance, they're strongly opposed to gay marriage, abortion, and birth control, which can make it difficult for those with differing opinions to feel welcomed. If the Church were to adopt a more contemporary mindset, I think they could maintain a strong base of followers. I've also heard that more people are turning against the Church due to their stance on these issues, and it's causing a bit of a division. While the Church is against abortion, if someone is for it, they might not want to be part of a community that sees it as completely wrong. Similarly, if someone supports gay marriage, they might not want to follow a Church that doesn't agree with that. I don't see a reason why priests couldn't be married or why women couldn't be priests. However, I'm not sure if these changes would have prevented the declining following. After all, the Church did something that might not have been affected by these changes. If priests were allowed to marry, would they have done things differently? It's hard to say. However, I don't see why priests can't have both their religious devotion and their family life, just like everyone else.

I'm not opposed to gay marriage. I believe that whether someone is gay or not is not a conscious choice they make. So I don't think gay people should be held responsible for their sexual orientation. It's not right to say that a man and a woman can get married but two people of the same sex can't. It's not a choice like they don't have a say in how they are born. I mean, I was born straight, and I didn't choose that either. It doesn't seem like they can be held accountable for something they can't change. I don't think the federal government should be involved because it's not a legal or moral issue. It's not about national security or anything like that. They shouldn't interfere in people's lives because being gay is just how they were born. They shouldn't be punished for that. That's it.

I believe that gay marriage should be legalized. Here are some reasons why:

Many people argue that allowing same-sex couples to marry would pose a threat to traditional families, but I think it’s a misconception. The dynamics of a relationship are so varied and complex that comparing it to something as simple as a coin isn’t quite accurate. Heterosexual and homosexual couples have the same basic elements that contribute to a successful and satisfying relationship, like love, commitment, and shared values.

Moreover, many civil rights protections are tied to marriage, such as property rights and healthcare benefits. For instance, a partner in a same-sex relationship might not be allowed to visit their spouse in the hospital, and they might not be able to make medical decisions on behalf of their partner. This can be unfair if you’re spending the rest of your life with someone.

Scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples are just as successful as heterosexual couples, with similar factors contributing to relationship satisfaction. It’s a relationship, plain and simple. Many people seem to get hung up on the idea that homosexuals are asking for the right to get married in a church, but what they’re really asking for is a legal document provided by the government. If there’s no involvement from the church, I don’t see why there should be an issue.

Legalizing gay marriage is similar to the segregation but separate issue. It’s unfair and unequal. Just like heterosexual couples, homosexual couples can take on different roles in the relationship, and they have the same potential for community involvement. The concern about children of gay couples is a valid one, but it’s too early to say how they’ll be affected. The main concern is how children get treated by their peers and by society, which is often a reflection of societal attitudes.

The federal government should be actively involved in making gay marriage legal in every state. I think an amendment should be crafted that supports, rather than opposes, this right. However, I’m not sure about the political aspects, as I don’t follow politics closely. Most of the reasons I’ve heard, including from President Bush, are based on moral grounds. Morality is highly subjective and varies from person to person, so it’s unethical to create laws that enforce one group’s morality on the entire country.

It’s also important to note that many people are against gay marriage because they believe that gay people are somehow psychologically damaged and that their sexual orientation is a result of trauma or a personality defect. This is not backed by psychological research. Institutions that have studied these issues, like the American Psychological Association, have shown that this misconception is false. If more people listened to these institutions and less to popular opinion, societal attitudes might change.

In conclusion, I believe that legalizing gay marriage is the right thing to do. It’s about love and commitment, and it should be treated with the same respect and dignity as any other relationship.

Well first off, I work in a hospital pharmacy this summer and let me tell you, just because a drug is outlawed doesn't mean it lacks beneficial properties. Take oxycodone, for instance—it's a controlled substance, but we use it all the time because it's beneficial. Similarly, I'm not saying I'd put marijuana out there for the public to use freely, but I think it can have medicinal benefits when used responsibly.

You know, there are so many illegal drugs that pharmacies use every day. Vicodin, Percocet—those are known to be addictive, but they're used because they're beneficial. Denying that doesn't make sense to me. I think we should embrace the beneficial properties of marijuana, but it's got to be done responsibly.

I don't think marijuana is as bad as the taboo around it suggests. It's not like heroin or cocaine. I'd say we should gradually integrate it into society, removing the stigma first. Then, perhaps people could use it responsibly. It's a tough call, but I think it's worth considering.

I believe the church has evolved to adapt to the 21st century. It's no longer as rigid as it once was. As a child, I would attend church every Sunday, dressed in matching outfits with my friends from our private school. Nowadays, the church has introduced youth services, which are much shorter, and people are more casual, even arriving in beachwear during the summer. The morning masses have also relaxed, with people wearing jeans and khakis. While I'm unsure of the church's political stance, this is the most significant change I've noticed. Regarding the accusations against Catholic priests and pedophilia, I think these issues could not have been prevented by changes like allowing female priests or married priests. Pedophilia is often linked to genetics, not just the environment. Even if priests were allowed to marry, their predispositions wouldn't change. If a man is genetically inclined to be a pedophile, he would likely still act on it, regardless of his marital status. I believe the church could have done more to address these issues if they were aware and covering them up, but I suspect not all cases were known.

(Laughs)
Initially, I was okay with the initial premise, but I think that everyone was still very much in shock from the September 11th attacks. And I believe that we invaded Iraq under a false pretext, that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction and was connected to the attacks. But all of this has since been proven false, and it really rubs me the wrong way. It just seems to me that the Bush administration openly lied to the American people and has yet to take responsibility for those lies.

Colin Powell, for instance, has said that he wasn't convinced by the evidence he presented at the UN. That's malfeasance in office, an impeachable offense. The Bush administration has shown a complete disregard for the Constitution, trying to marginalize it since September 11th. They came into office with a clear intention to go to war. Paul O’Neill, the Secretary of the Treasury who was seemingly forced out of his office, mentioned this in his book. It seems that the younger Bush had a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein, and he wanted to expand our energy supply in the long term.

I think the war has gone on long enough, but I'm not sure if pulling out now would be a good idea. The country could lapse into civil war and result in even more deaths. The alternative, a coalition of nations from surrounding areas like Syria and Saudi Arabia, doesn't seem ideal either, as it could lead to more problems with Iraq's sovereignty. The interim government seems to be dissolving, and the Parliament isn't very effective. The political process is also experiencing a lot of friction due to radical elements vying for control.

I can't articulate these thoughts in polite company.

I've done it. Just talking into it, right? Okay, cool. Mm-hmm. Uh-huh. Alright, I'm sorry. How about the War in Iraq? Well, let me think. Umm, at this point, I feel it's kind of pointless. It's not even a declared war, really. It feels like we're just trying to get back at Iraq because we figured they were behind the terrorist attacks on 9/11. I mean, I'm not into this whole War on Iraq thing, so I don't keep up with the details. But as of now, we're over there trying to build democracy and, of course, get their oil. But it's not a good enough reason to stay. If we leave, they'll be upset because we'll have messed everything up. They'll have to start over, and it'll take forever for them to build a democracy. It's hard, man. I don't know. It's like we're trying to make them into another United States, but it's not their culture. It's just gonna make things worse for them. I mean, it's hard to say I want them out of there, but if we stay, it's gonna hurt us in the end. It's like the Vietnam War all over again, except this time, it's Bush who'll have to deal with being the president who started a meaningless war. It's hard to say I want it to end because so many families have sons and daughters over there, and we've destroyed their lives. But it's also hard to say I want them to stay because of the culture clash. I don't know, man. It's gonna go on for years, it seems. That's about it.

I don't think it's right to legalize it, and I don't believe a state should even declare it legal. I feel this is really up to the churches, as the constitution states separation of church and state. It's explicitly clear, and I don't think trying to impose any power over it would be right, as it goes against what's already in the constitution. In my opinion, trying to enforce any kind of power over it would be in defiance of what has already been said and written in stone.

I think those who are trying to make it illegal are choosing one church's beliefs over another. Most Catholics and Christians are against it, and don't support it, except for in Boston and some areas like that. I don't think it's up to the government to decide what churches can and can't make illegal or legal. Separation of church and state has been a key aspect of the constitution, allowing for religious tolerance in the United States. I don't think making an amendment about it would be right or even contradictory to what's already been said and written. It would be one of the few amendments that would restrict the people rather than the government.

I don't believe the federal government, or any government, should be involved in this issue. The push for this amendment is likely driven by personal religious beliefs, as the person pushing it is a Catholic. Their push for the amendment is just showing a preference for their religion over others. I really feel it's up to the churches to decide this, not the president or any government official. There isn't any substantial reason backing it up, other than personal views. I don't see how it's going to impact the economy or society in any significant way, and in fact, it might have a positive impact on society.

The war in Iraq is a topic that has sparked much debate over the years. Let me start by saying I believe that the government was not fully truthful with the American people about the reasons for going to war. I think the invasion was seen as a way to connect Iraq to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, when in reality, the two events had little to do with each other. The government played on the emotions of the American people, who were outraged by the September 11th attacks, to gain support for the invasion, which began in 2003.

I personally am against war, especially preemptive strikes. I believe that the war in Iraq is, in many ways, a repeat of the Vietnam War. The government failed to learn from past mistakes and was not prepared for the aftermath of removing the Iraqi government and the chaos that would ensue. The United States was removing the Iraqi government and trying to implement a democratic government, similar to what was attempted in Vietnam. However, the government did not anticipate the insurgency that would arise, as fighting citizens rather than a well-defined army is much more challenging.

Firstly, I don't think we should have gotten into the war in the first place. But if we were to engage in war, we need to plan for all possible outcomes. I believe the government was not as prepared as it should have been. They did not anticipate the void of power and the chaos that would occur after removing the Iraqi government. Despite being there for several years, the United States is still trying to train Iraqi troops and police forces to police their own country. It's a long process, and I think the government made it seem like it would be a short, successful stay in Iraq.

The war in Iraq is a tough decision to make because we've been there for so long. Once we've committed to a war, it's hard to abandon the people we've removed the government from. We took away their way of life, so how can we abandon them? It's a difficult choice between trying to finish the job and considering the risk we're taking for a free democratic Iraq. The question of why Iraq was invaded while other countries with known weapons of mass destruction, like North Korea, were not, raises the issue of the oil industry. It's a complex issue with a lot of money and resource control at play.

I just hope that the war ends soon and that there will be peace in Iraq. But I'm not optimistic that this will happen anytime soon.

Let's see, I've always been in support of gay marriage. I believe it's a personal preference, and science has shown that it's often biological rather than sociological, making it unfair to deny rights based on something that's largely out of people's control. It's also cruel and inhumane. I've been an advocate for it for a long time. I don't think politics or the government should play a role, as it's a personal and household issue, not something to be decided at the state or national level. In my neighborhood, there are a couple of openly gay couples who function just like any other family. Bush's attempt to interpret marriage in his own way is ridiculous. Maybe it's because marriage is something two people can choose to do privately without much fuss, but if two gay people want to do it, it becomes a public spectacle. I think it should be a private, personal matter, not something the public or government gets involved in.

No, there's no turning back.

You know, when you share something online, it's basically a public forum. Everything you put out there is visible to everyone. It can shape people's opinions about you, especially if it's something serious, like talking about violence or harmful activities. The internet is a global platform, and if you're friends with someone on Myspace, their bulletins will show up on your page. Someone at school might see something concerning and report it, as they can't afford to ignore potential threats. However, some people might just be fooling around, making it hard to discern what's serious. In our school, someone overheard a concerning statement and reported it to the authorities. They found that the person had made some worrying posts on Facebook that could have been taken seriously. So, if you don't want something to be public, don't put it online. If you don't want people to find it or form certain opinions, you can't control that. If you're an R.A. and you're friends with your residents on social media, you might see posts that you don't want to see, like pictures of them drinking or engaging in other activities. While I don't think school officials should friend students, if something is brought to their attention, they have a responsibility to take it seriously. They shouldn't be monitoring phone conversations or texts, but if they receive a report about a potential threat, they have to act accordingly.

I feel like the war has been stretched out too long. Initially, the purpose was noble—to restore democracy in a country without a fair political system. But I believe we've lost sight of that aim and now we're just fighting to prove our global dominance. Perhaps there were even personal motivations tied to George Bush's father's previous conflicts with Saddam Hussein. If the original intention was to bring democracy to a tyrannical regime, that would be justifiable. However, I think our reasons have become muddled and our purpose has been lost over time, as we seem to be fighting for the sake of fighting. I believe it has dragged on long enough and should come to a conclusion soon. After all, there comes a point when the local government must take charge. We've been draining our own economy by spending billions on a foreign war while facing our own domestic issues like poverty and infrastructure. This money could be better spent on addressing our own pressing needs, such as healthcare and school improvements. War is not a long-term expense, and there are more pressing issues to address. The ongoing war is a drain on our resources that could be more effectively used to solve our own problems.

Can I ask a question to clarify something? Someone found that post online and took action to prevent it because of what they saw. I don't think it was an invasion of privacy at all. On sites like Myspace, if you post information publicly, it's fair game for anyone to see, as long as you're okay with it. Maybe the person who saw the post was doing their job, or maybe they were just curious. Either way, I'm glad they intervened and prevented a life from being lost.

It's a tough situation, though. You can't have one person monitoring everyone's profiles all day, but it's not fair to target only certain students. It all depends on the situation. I don't have a Myspace, but I do have a Facebook, and it bothers me knowing that strangers can see personal information about me. I've seen things on TV where people can find out so much about others just by looking at their profiles.

I've had people IM me and know who I am without me knowing their screen name. It's disconcerting to think that someone knows my interests, where I am during the day, and who my friends are. I try to limit what I post, but at the same time, I want to communicate with friends. It's a tricky situation, and I only accept people I know as friends.

My roommate's high school banned students from having Myspace, which I thought was strange. I'm not sure how they had the right to do that.

I must admit, I feel that gender discrimination is still a significant issue in the United States. It's not confined to women but affects various fields and roles, often based on societal expectations and stereotypes.

For instance, in the workplace, women continue to face challenges in breaking through the "glass ceiling." Even when they possess all the necessary qualifications, some boards may hesitate to promote them to top positions simply because historically women have not held such roles in the business world.

Moreover, men also experience discrimination, particularly in fields like fashion or when they choose to stay at home as primary caregivers. Society often expects men to be the sole breadwinners, leading to judgment and disapproval when they deviate from this norm.

In the fashion industry, men are sometimes not taken seriously due to their interest in a field traditionally dominated by women. This can lead to doubts about their understanding and experience with women's fashion.

Regardless of the field, I believe gender discrimination persists due to societal setbacks in mindset and acceptance. While significant progress has been made, societal changes take time. Women are increasingly moving into leadership roles, and men are becoming more accepted as primary caregivers, but these shifts are gradual.

To effect change, we need to promote the positive qualities of those stereotypically discriminated against, rather than being overly insistent. If we attempt to enforce change too quickly, people may resist. I believe we're already on the right path, with women rising to higher positions and men being more accepted in traditional female roles. However, we must continue to work at this pace to ensure sustained progress.

Furthermore, discrimination can also occur based on factors like socioeconomic background and grammar. For example, someone from a farm with excellent intelligence but poor grammar might face judgments from others, underscoring the multifaceted nature of discrimination.

In conclusion, while significant strides have been made, there's still much work to be done to achieve true equality across all areas of society.

In my opinion, decriminalization is the new approach to marijuana laws, which changes it from a criminal offense to more of a minor infraction, similar to a traffic ticket. This means that people caught with marijuana are cited rather than arrested. However, the long-term consequences of a marijuana charge, such as the stigma in job interviews and other areas of life, still exist.

There's an argument that decriminalization could save money for communities that are financially struggling. The costs of arrests, trials, and legal representation can be significant. In places like Denver, where people generally hold more open-minded views, decriminalization is well-received, freeing up money for public education, social programs, and other community needs.

While I understand the financial benefits, I also believe in being cautious about the public's perception of marijuana. Legalization could lead to it being sold and used openly, much like cigarettes, which could be awkward and problematic in many contexts. Additionally, the effects of marijuana can differ greatly from person to person, with some people being more adversely affected than others.

I don't have a strong opinion one way or the other, but I think it's important to consider all the factors involved.

I'd say yes, because
- A lot of what they do is quite traditional, like they've maintained certain practices for long periods of time.
- It's good to stay connected to tradition, but it's also important to be adaptable to change.
- Many Catholics feel obligated to attend Church every week and are quite strict about how things are done.
- Sometimes, I feel like the Catholic Church looks down on those who don't fully adhere to the doctrine.
- They also aren't very accepting of other religions, as seen in the case of my parents' interfaith marriage.
- My mom was an Episcopalian, and my dad was also Episcopalian. Despite their love for each other, they weren't married in the Catholic Church due to my dad's religious background.
- This isn't really a display of tolerance for other religions.
- We've been taught to love others, which is a Catholic principle, but it's hypocritical to say one thing and then not act on it.
- I feel that a lot of Catholic doctrine dictates specific actions, but the actual practice often goes against these teachings.
- I don't think allowing priests to marry would necessarily stop pedophilic behavior.
- Children are much more vulnerable than spouses, so I think child molestation would happen regardless of whether priests are married or not.
- Allowing priests to marry wouldn't solve the problem of pedophilic behavior.

I grew up in a Christian household, so my stance on homosexuality is a bit complicated. I have many gay friends, but I don’t necessarily agree with their lifestyle. However, I believe it should be legalized. I don’t think it should be a national issue, but rather something each state decides on its own. For instance, many states are Democratic, and they tend to push for gay marriage. If you live in a Democratic state, you should respect the state's decision on the matter. I think homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I feel it should be legalized based on the discretion of each state. I don't agree with President Bush's ban on gay marriage; he shouldn't be able to decide how every state runs itself. He won't be in office for much longer, and if a Democratic president decides to lift the ban, it would just be a back-and-forth battle. It should be left up to each individual state, as they are the ones who will have to live with the decision. I don't think it should be a matter for the presidency to decide.

No way, no I don't at all. Let me see, I think it's like this: Myspace is public, and a bulletin board is a place where you post things for others to see. If you put something on the internet, you should expect that people will see it, whether it's school officials or not. If they see something that could prevent a school shooting, they have every right to do so. It's all about keeping students safe. School officials should only use it to make the school safer, not just to catch students doing something wrong. It's okay if they do it to protect students, but they shouldn't just snoop around. It's a public space, and students should know that. They shouldn't post things they don't want others to see. If they do, they should expect consequences. Once it's on the internet, it's there forever. It's just like not wanting to say something bad about someone in an email because it could come back to haunt you. Same with posting on Myspace. If you do something in college, it could come back when you're older. It's all about being careful with what you post. If something could make the school safer, school officials should use it. They're just doing their job to keep students safe. It's like how we practiced lock downs in school in response to terrorist attacks. They're just ensuring the school is a safe space for students.
